verses.text: This is what the Lord says: 'See, I will stir up a destroying wind against Babylon and against those who dwell in Leb-kamai.'
verses.comment: Leb-kamai is a code name for Babylon. The 'destroying wind' symbolizes God's judgment. The language here foreshadows God's sovereign power over nations.

verses.text: And I will send foreigners to Babylon, who will winnow her and empty her land; for in the day of disaster, they shall be against her on every side.
verses.comment: Winnowing refers to separating wheat from chaff, illustrating total judgment. The mention of foreign attackers anticipates historical events when the Medes and Persians conquer Babylon.

verses.text: Let not the archer bend his bow, nor let him rise up in his armor. Do not spare her young men; destroy her entire army.
verses.comment: Total defeat is prophesied for Babylon. Emphasizes God's absolute justice against sin and pride.

verses.text: They shall fall slain in the land of the Chaldeans, and pierced through in her streets.
verses.comment: The Chaldeans refer to the Babylonians. The vision shows God's judgment affects every aspect of their society.

verses.text: For Israel and Judah are not forsaken by their God, the Lord of hosts, even though their land is full of guilt before the Holy One of Israel.
verses.comment: God's faithfulness to His people is shown despite their guilt; this foreshadows the faithfulness God later demonstrates in the New Covenant.

verses.text: Flee from the midst of Babylon! Let everyone save his life! Do not be cut off in her punishment, for this is the time of the Lord’s vengeance; He will repay her what she deserves.
verses.comment: There is a call for the faithful to come out from among the wicked, which echoes in the call of Revelation for Christians to separate from the world’s corruption.

verses.text: Babylon was a golden cup in the Lord’s hand, making all the earth drunk; the nations drank her wine, therefore the nations have gone mad.
verses.comment: Babylon’s influence over nations is described as intoxicating. This image is picked up in Revelation to signify worldly seduction and confusion.

verses.text: Suddenly Babylon has fallen and is shattered; wail for her! Take balm for her pain; perhaps she may be healed.
verses.comment: Healer imagery highlights how God offers opportunity for mercy, but true healing is absent apart from repentance.

verses.text: We would have healed Babylon, but she was not healed; forsake her, and let us each go to his own country, for her judgment reaches up to heaven and is lifted up to the skies.
verses.comment: Echoes Genesis 11 (Tower of Babel, Gen. 11:4). Universal consequences of sin require a universal solution, which is ultimately fulfilled in Christ.

verses.text: The Lord has brought forth our vindication; come, let us declare in Zion the work of the Lord our God.
verses.comment: Zion symbolizes true worship and spiritual homecoming, themes fulfilled in the unity of God’s people.

verses.text: Sharpen the arrows! Take up the shields! The Lord has stirred up the spirit of the kings of the Medes, because His plan is to destroy Babylon; for that is the vengeance of the Lord, the vengeance for His temple.
verses.comment: The Medes' conquest is both historical and a sign of God avenging the profanation of the Temple.

verses.text: Set up a standard against the walls of Babylon; strengthen the watch! Set watchmen, prepare the ambushes! For the Lord has both planned and done what He spoke concerning the people of Babylon.
verses.comment: The certainty of prophecy is underlined—what God declares, He brings to pass. This builds confidence in divine promises.

verses.text: O you who dwell by many waters, rich in treasures, your end has come, the measure of your greed.
verses.comment: Babylon’s wealth and pride are judged. Many waters symbolize both literal location and international influence.

verses.text: The Lord of hosts has sworn by Himself: Surely I will fill you with men like locusts, and they will shout a victory cry over you.
verses.comment: The locust imagery symbolizes overwhelming numbers, reminiscent of earlier biblical judgments.

verses.text: He made the earth by His power, established the world by His wisdom, and stretched out the heavens by His understanding.
verses.comment: God’s creative authority is highlighted, contrasting with Babylon’s idols. This sovereignty is echoed in Christ as the Word (see John 1:1-3).

verses.text: When He utters His voice, there is a tumult of waters in the heavens, and He causes the clouds to ascend from the ends of the earth. He makes lightning for the rain and brings forth the wind from His storehouses.
verses.comment: Nature obeys God’s command, underlining His unique power—a principle continuously affirmed through both Testaments.

verses.text: Every man is without knowledge and put to shame by his idols, for his molded images are false, and there is no breath in them.
verses.comment: Idolatry is condemned as ultimately deceptive and lifeless. This is a central reason for God’s judgment.

verses.text: They are worthless, a work of mockery; in the time of their punishment they shall perish.
verses.comment: Worship of anything other than God ends in shame and destruction.

verses.text: The portion of Jacob is not like these, for He is the Maker of all things; Israel is the tribe of His inheritance. The Lord of hosts is His name.
verses.comment: Israel’s God is uniquely alive and the true Creator. God’s election of His people is again proclaimed.

verses.text: You are My hammer and weapon of war. With you I break nations in pieces; with you I destroy kingdoms.
verses.comment: God uses His chosen instruments to bring about His will among nations, a foreshadowing of how He acts through His faithful.

verses.text: With you I break the horse and its rider; with you I break the chariot and its rider.
verses.comment: God’s power shatters all earthly might, recalling the Exodus.

verses.text: With you I break man and woman; with you I break old and young; with you I break the young man and the young woman.
verses.comment: All segments of society are judged by God’s instrument. This comprehensive justice also speaks to a coming, final judgment.

verses.text: With you I break the shepherd and his flock; with you I break the farmer and his team; with you I break governors and rulers.
verses.comment: No class or office is exempt from divine judgment. Humanity stands accountable.

verses.text: I will repay Babylon and all the inhabitants of Chaldea before your eyes for all the evil that they have done in Zion,' declares the Lord.
verses.comment: God’s justice includes vindicating His people and punishing those who defile what is holy.

verses.text: Behold, I am against you, O destroying mountain, who destroys the whole earth,' declares the Lord. 'I will stretch out My hand against you, roll you down from the rocks, and make you a burnt mountain.'
verses.comment: Babylon is depicted as a 'destroying mountain,' a symbol of worldly power set against God.

verses.text: No stone shall be taken from you for a corner nor any stone for a foundation, but you shall be a desolate waste forever,' declares the Lord.
verses.comment: Babylon will not be rebuilt—its fate is final, unlike God’s eternal Kingdom.

verses.text: Raise a banner in the land; blow the trumpet among the nations! Prepare the nations for war against her; summon the kingdoms against her—Ararat, Minni, and Ashkenaz. Appoint a commander against her; bring up horses like bristling locusts!
verses.comment: Eastern powers are summoned against Babylon. The gathering of nations for judgment echoes prophetic visions of the end-times.

verses.text: Prepare the nations for war against her, the kings of the Medes, with their governors and all their officials, and all the countries they rule.
verses.comment: Emphasizes the might of the invading coalition—human plans serving God’s greater judgment.

verses.text: The land trembles and writhes, for the Lord's intentions against Babylon stand—to make the land of Babylon a waste without inhabitants.
verses.comment: All creation responds to God’s decrees. Even the land is affected by spiritual realities.

verses.text: Babylon's warriors have ceased fighting; they remain in their strongholds; their strength has failed; they have become like women. Her dwellings are set on fire; her bars are broken.
verses.comment: The defenders’ impotence illustrates how resistance is pointless against the Lord’s decree.

verses.text: One runner runs to meet another, and one messenger to meet another, to announce to the king of Babylon that his city is captured on every side.
verses.comment: Swift communication of defeat underscores the total collapse of Babylon’s defenses.

verses.text: The fords have been seized, the marshes are burned with fire, and the warriors are in panic.
verses.comment: The strategic points are controlled by the invaders, portraying thorough conquest.

verses.text: For thus says the Lord of hosts, the God of Israel: Babylon is like a threshing floor at the time when it is trodden; yet a little while and the time of harvest will come for her.
verses.comment: Using agricultural imagery, this presents God’s judgment as a harvest—see Jesus’ own parables about harvest at the end of the age (Matt. 13:39).

verses.text: Nebuchadnezzar king of Babylon has devoured me, he has crushed me, he has made me an empty vessel. He has swallowed me like a monster; he filled his stomach with my delicacies, he has rinsed me out.
verses.comment: Vivid poetic language shows the thorough devastation of God’s people.

verses.text: The violence done to me and to my flesh be upon Babylon,' let the inhabitant of Zion say. 'My blood be upon the inhabitants of Chaldea!' let Jerusalem say.
verses.comment: A call for just retribution, reflecting the biblical principle that God avenges injustice (Rom. 12:19).

verses.text: Therefore thus says the Lord: Behold, I will plead your cause and take vengeance for you. I will dry up her sea and make her fountain dry.
verses.comment: God Himself arises as advocate for His people, a foreshadowing of Christ’s mediatorial role.

verses.text: And Babylon shall become a heap of ruins, a haunt of jackals, a horror and a hissing, without inhabitant.
verses.comment: The prophecy’s fulfillment is historical, and is echoed in the New Testament image of Babylon as the world set against God.

verses.text: They shall roar together like lions; they shall growl like lion cubs.
verses.comment: Describes Babylon’s pride, arrogance, and their impending sudden demise.

verses.text: While they are inflamed, I will prepare their feast and make them drunk, that they may rejoice, then sleep a perpetual sleep and not wake,' declares the Lord.
verses.comment: The idea of drunkenness here is figurative, pointing to sudden destruction during arrogant celebration (see Daniel 5).

verses.text: I will bring them down like lambs to the slaughter, like rams with male goats.
verses.comment: Judgment will be total and inescapable.

verses.text: How Sheshach is taken, the pride of the whole earth seized! How Babylon has become a horror among the nations!
verses.comment: Sheshach is a cryptic term for Babylon. Babylon’s fall is a lesson for all nations.

verses.text: The sea has come up on Babylon; she is covered with the tumult of its waves.
verses.comment: Symbolizes both literal flooding and overwhelming conquest.

verses.text: Her cities have become a horror, a land of drought and desert, a land in which no one dwells, through which no son of man passes.
verses.comment: Contrasts the former glory with now total desolation.

verses.text: I will punish Bel in Babylon and make him vomit out what he has swallowed. The nations shall no longer stream to him; the wall of Babylon has fallen.
verses.comment: Bel was Babylon’s main idol. God will break the spiritual power behind oppression—contesting false spiritualities.

verses.text: Come out of her, My people! Let everyone save his life from the fierce anger of the Lord!
verses.comment: Repeated call for the remnant to come out anticipates the spiritual call for the faithful in every age.

verses.text: Do not faint or be dismayed at the rumor heard in the land. For in one year one rumor will come, and after that, in another year, another; violence shall be in the land, and ruler against ruler.
verses.comment: God’s people are told not to panic at rumors, echoing the call for steadfast trust in turbulent times.

verses.text: Therefore, behold, the days are coming when I will punish the images of Babylon; her whole land will be put to shame, and all her slain shall fall in her midst.
verses.comment: Idolatry brings shame and ruin—major biblical theme culminating in the worship of the one true God.

verses.text: Then the heavens and the earth and all that is in them shall sing for joy over Babylon, for the destroyers shall come against her from the north,' announces the Lord.
verses.comment: All creation rejoices at God’s righteous judgments—parallels the joy in God’s final victory in Revelation.

verses.text: Babylon must fall for the slain of Israel, just as for Babylon have fallen the slain of all the earth.
verses.comment: God’s justice is reciprocal—both judgment and mercy are displayed.

verses.text: You who have escaped the sword, go! Do not stand still! Remember the Lord from far away, and let Jerusalem come into your mind.
verses.comment: The call to remember Jerusalem foreshadows the central place of God’s city in salvation history.

verses.text: We are put to shame, for we have heard reproach; shame has covered our faces, for foreigners have come into the holy places of the Lord's house.
verses.comment: The desecration of the sanctuary brings grief; later fulfilled in Christ’s zeal for the sanctity of the Temple (John 2:14-17).

verses.text: Therefore, behold, the days are coming, declares the Lord, when I will punish her idols, and through all her land the wounded shall groan.
verses.comment: Judgment continues until idolatry is extinguished from the land.

verses.text: Though Babylon should ascend to heaven, and though she fortify her high stronghold, yet destroyers will come from Me against her, declares the Lord.
verses.comment: Echoes the pride of Babel; even heavenly heights cannot shield from God’s judgment—pride always fails before Him.

verses.text: A sound of cry comes from Babylon, and great destruction from the land of the Chaldeans!
For the Lord is laying Babylon waste and silencing her loud voice. Their waves roar like many waters; the noise of their voice resounds.
verses.comment: The Lord silences Babylon’s pride and tumult.

verses.text: For a destroyer has come against her, against Babylon; her warriors are taken, their bows are broken to pieces; for the Lord is a God of recompense, He will surely repay.
verses.comment: God’s perfect justice returns on oppressors what they have done to others.

verses.text: I will make her princes and her wise men drunk, her governors, her officials, and her warriors; they shall sleep a perpetual sleep and not wake, declares the King, whose name is the Lord of hosts.
verses.comment: Leaders themselves are judged; God’s sovereignty is total, even over rulers.

verses.text: Thus says the Lord of hosts: The broad wall of Babylon shall be leveled to the ground, and her high gates shall be burned with fire. The peoples labor in vain, and the nations weary themselves for nothing.
verses.comment: The futility of human achievement apart from God—a recurring biblical theme.

verses.text: The word that Jeremiah the prophet commanded Seraiah the son of Neriah, the son of Mahseiah, when he went with Zedekiah king of Judah to Babylon in the fourth year of his reign. Seraiah was the quartermaster.
verses.comment: Historical note provides details of how the prophecy was delivered and by whom.

verses.text: Jeremiah wrote in a book all the disaster that was to come upon Babylon, all these words that are written concerning Babylon.
verses.comment: Shows the importance of the written Word as a lasting witness.

verses.text: And Jeremiah said to Seraiah: 'When you come to Babylon, see that you read all these words,
verses.comment: Public reading of Scripture is central for God’s people, foreshadowing the communal life of worship and proclamation.

verses.text: 'and say, O Lord, you have said concerning this place that you will cut it off, so that nothing shall dwell in it, neither man nor beast, and it shall be desolate forever.'
verses.comment: Affirms that God’s word will infallibly come to pass (see Isa. 55:11).

verses.text: When you finish reading this book, tie a stone to it and throw it into the middle of the Euphrates,
verses.comment: The physical action symbolizes the total and irreversible judgment decreed upon Babylon.

verses.text: and say, 'So shall Babylon sink, and not rise again because of the disaster I will bring upon her, and her people will be weary.' Thus far are the words of Jeremiah.
verses.comment: Babylon’s fate prefigures the final end of all that is opposed to God’s Kingdom. God’s word concludes with assurance: His plans will not fail.
